misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program solves a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the required grade-to-letter conversion. It reads four coordinate values rather than a single numeric grade and never handles grade values or letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit this program that reads x1, y1, x2, y2 and computes the distance between two points for the grade calculator question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: Input prompts refer to coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) rather than a grade.
The program reads four double values instead of one numeric grade.
No variables or prompts use the word 'grade'.
No letter grade is ever computed or printed.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment or accidental submission of code from a different exercise (distance between points), rather than misunderstanding of Java syntax.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and ensure your program’s inputs and outputs match it exactly. Replace the coordinate inputs with a single numeric grade (0–100) and adjust prompts accordingly.
related_concepts: Mapping program inputs/outputs to a textual description
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (class name, prompts, variables, and final output) refers to distance between points; there is no mention of grades or letters.

evidence.note: The entire main method is dedicated to reading two points and computing their distance; there is no grade input or grade-related logic.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program contains no conditional statements to check numeric ranges or map values to letter grades. As a result, the required A–F grade scale is never implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: Computing and printing a single numeric result (the distance) is sufficient; no if-else logic is necessary for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To convert a numeric grade to a letter grade, the program must use conditional logic (if/else-if/else or equivalent) to test the grade against the specified ranges (90–100 for A, 80–89 for B, etc.) and choose the correct letter.
symptoms: No if, else-if, else, or switch statements in the program.
No Boolean expressions that check whether a value lies within a numeric range.
Output is a numeric distance, not a categorical letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student wrote code for a different numerical computation task and never attempted to design the branching logic required for mapping numeric ranges to categories.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After fixing the input to read a single grade, add an if/else-if/else chain to test the grade against each range (>=90, >=80, etc.) and print the corresponding letter. Review examples of range-based grading programs.
related_concepts: Designing control flow from problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The body of main performs only a straight-line distance computation with no branching, so the grade range logic is completely absent.

evidence.note: Straight-line computation from inputs to a numeric result; there are no conditional statements implementing grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Solved Incorrect Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete and functional program for calculating the distance between two points, which is a different assignment. This program does not read a grade, implement grading logic, or output a letter grade as required by Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely believes this is the correct solution for Q3, possibly due to submitting the wrong file or confusion between assignment questions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads four floating-point numbers (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Code uses methods from the Math library (sqrt, pow)
Code outputs 'The distance of the two points is...'
No conditional (if/else) logic is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or confusion over which problem (Q3: Grade Calculator) was being addressed/submitted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the code specifically written for the Grade Calculator problem (Q3). Ensure your solution reads one integer grade and uses 'if/else if/else' structures to determine the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entirety of the submitted code implements the distance formula, leaving no ambiguity that the student solved the wrong problem.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the program is for calculating distance, not grades.
Code reads four coordinates (doubles) instead of one grade (integer).

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The core logic calculates and outputs distance based on the coordinates, with no conditional grade checks.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - wrong problem submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a distance calculation problem instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. The code does not attempt to read a grade, apply grade ranges, or output a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a problem about calculating the distance between two points, or has submitted code from the wrong assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100), comparing it against ranges (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60), and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads two coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value
Output is a floating-point distance, not a letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Class is named DistanceBetweenPoints, not related to grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the assignment requirements, or submission of code from a different problem/assignment
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Read a single numeric grade. Use if-else statements to check: if (grade >= 90) output 'A', else if (grade >= 80) output 'B', and so on.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The divergence is absolute and unmistakable. The student has submitted code for a completely different problem. This is not ambiguous or interpretable as an attempt at the grade calculator.

evidence.note: Entire submission solves distance calculation, not grade conversion. Reads coordinate pairs instead of a single grade, and outputs distance instead of letter grade.
Wrong input prompt and wrong number of inputs. Should read one grade value (0-100), not coordinate pairs.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Wrong output: calculates and displays Euclidean distance. Should instead output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (distance between points) instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two 2D points rather than reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional logic. As a result, none of the required grade-calculation behavior (single grade input, range checks for A–F, letter output) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them, or they did not attend to the specific problem statement for the grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding:
For this question, the program should:
1) Read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user.
2) Use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to test which range the grade falls into: 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, or below 60.
3) Print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) in the specified format, e.g., "Letter grade: B".
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
Program uses double variables x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a numeric grade variable.
Program computes a square root and powers to find distance rather than using conditional logic on a grade.
No if/else or Boolean range checks appear anywhere in the code.
Output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment or reuse of code from a different exercise (distance between points) without adapting it to the grade-calculation specification. This reflects a procedural issue in mapping the problem statement to an appropriate algorithm, rather than a small syntax or off-by-one error.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or ignore the current distance-calculation logic and start from the problem specification: read a single integer or double grade from 0 to 100, then write an if/else-if/else chain such as `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } ... else { ... }` to choose the correct letter. Finally, print `Letter grade: X` where X is A, B, C, D, or F. Double-check that the prompts and variable names (e.g., `grade`) match the problem description.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, variables, and formula match a standard distance-between-points exercise and contain no elements of a grade calculator (no single grade input, no conditionals, no letter output), so it is very unlikely this was intended as a grade-calculator implementation.

evidence.note: This code clearly reads four coordinates and computes a distance; it never reads a single grade, never uses any conditional statements for grade ranges, and never prints a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Submitting Incorrect Code for the Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of writing a program to calculate a letter grade based on a numeric score (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied and pasted the wrong file, or fundamentally misunderstood which problem they were supposed to be solving, resulting in an entirely incorrect program being submitted for Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must address the specified requirements of the assignment: reading a single integer input (the grade) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: The code uses input variables (x1, y1, x2, y2) unrelated to the problem.
The primary calculation is for distance using the distance formula.
No conditional logic (if-statements) is present to determine a letter grade.
The code produces output completely unrelated to the required letter grade assignment.
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismanagement of files or confusion about which problem statement corresponds to which code solution. This might be a mistake in the submission process rather than a pure coding misconception.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment requirements carefully and ensure you submit the correct file containing the solution for the Grade Calculator problem (Q3).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves the distance formula problem, which is 100% incorrect for the Grade Calculator problem specified.

evidence.note: The entire code implements the distance formula, not the grade calculator required for Q3. Inputs are for coordinates, not a grade.
